description.text: James Shannon (1/19/2015)

Xmas Vacation Eggnog Mug http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fKncYRJQRC8 Oh yes, I am not cooking or heating anything in this and do not intend to let any contents reside in it for very long. I intend to hand wash them after every use. After making a couple I decided to revise this and created a second larger version. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:70309

Print the mug and two antlers (brown ABS if you have it or color it later). Clean up the tapered dovetail features until the antler tenon slips in & locks over the bump at the bottom of the mug's mortise. Print at least two, one for you and an associate - or as many as you need.
I included an antler stl oriented flat since it was oriented oddly for printing when I drew it, you only need the flat orientation - structurally the dovetail feature would be stronger in this orientation due to the graininess of 3D printing, but mine are strong enough in the flat orientation and they were easier to print in the flat orientation.
Darken the eyes and nose with a colored pencil or by some other means, which will not be dissolved or wash off with a seal.
Seal for leaks with a wash of acetone and/or abs juice.
For storage between eggnog times, the antlers will slide off and nicely fit inside.
CAPACITY: These comfortably hold 100 ml (3+ oz) with brim room for walking about.

A light sculpture inspired by bioluminescent jellies and other sea critters. Powered by an Arduino. The lights are AdaFruit NeoPixels. The ribs rest on a 3/4" wooden dowel and some 3/16" acrylic rods. The Arduino program slowly and randomly changes the colors of the LEDs. The acrylic rods can hold the structure up with the dowel, which can be slid out the top. Bulbs (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:561399) attach very easily with hot glue to the NeoPixel strips.

I worked with a client who had no useable fingers - one arm was amputated and the fingers on the other hand were fused.  She could not open the microwave because her microwave had a button that had to be pushed in about an inch (a very common design) to open the door. She could not do this because she had no fingers.  She had a pencil that she could hold and sometimes open the microwave, but this didn't work well - she also had severe vision loss (why the 3D printed part is bright green, BTW).  She could get food out of  her refrigerator and eat it by herself, but it was often cold because of the difficulty of using the microwave.  
This device creates a slider and a track (two tracks in the file - one screws into the countertop, one can be glued or secured with double-sided tape).  The slider can be pushed with a forearm or a clubbed hand, and the slider pushes the microwave door button.  
The slider and track should be aligned with the microwave button so that the pusher makes full contact with the button.  When the door is shut, the button pops back into place, pushing the slider back to the front of the track.  
This gave her the ability to easily open the microwave and heat up her food - by herself.

comments.text: We glued a plastic furniture bumper on the Start / +30 second button.  This means that button sticks out from the microwave.  The person could then bump that button with the back of her hand.  The buttons on the front are digital buttons and require a lot less force than the main "door" button which is a purely mechanical linkage. We adapted the Stop button and the +30 button this way.  She could add 30 seconds by brushing the right side of the panel, or stop by brushing the middle with the back of her hand.  The furniture bumpers are visible on a couple of the photos above.

description.text:
Better, Improved. - Now on "V2" - Slightly longer Heel. it'll work better - trust me. Aluminium Section 80mm These fit Standard 80mm Aluminium Section. Based on a design which worked, but I wasn't happy with:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:637773 Ok, so why are they shown in pairs?
See the Spiggot on the upper side of the Hooks (Nearest Front on the Thingiview which I can't seem to rearrange) - that prints upwards. That fits into a socket which is printed on the underside of the hooks. Now both the dia 12mm hook (actually Ø12.5mm) and the dia 16mm (actually Ø16.2mm) WILL fit together, but I intend the two hooks of the same sizes to be interlocked: this prevents the hooks rotating out and releasing. It's up to you! This was made for the Aluminium section in our lab, which has shed loads of pneumatic pipes everywhere so this will help me organise the place. I have 2 of each on print. The "Impossible bolt and nut" is an amusing 3D-printable two-part assembly with a working thread, where a nut is trapped on a bolt.  
The single STL file contains the nut placed at a slight distance from the bolt's head. The gap between both is sized to create a "skipped" layer thus making a fracture plane so that the nut can be removed from bolt's head.  
We have supplied several STL files scaled to commonly available 3D-print heights. Please choose the one that closest fits your desired print height. It is possible to scale the STL up or down with successful results.  
Please see instructions for more information on how to 3D-print this bolt and nut.  Also note that some slicing software and settings could interpret the air gap as an STL defect and remove the gap during print. You will have to disable the STL heal function.

description.header: Download the STL files and 3D-print your own!  :)

description.text: http://youtu.be/GbDMlNjrUM4
Home - Youtube - Things - #3DBenchy - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Instructables - Instagram - Pinterest - Flickr - LinkedIn

There is a gap between the nut and the bolt's head. The size is adjusted so that the slicing software will "skip" a layer.   
This air gap should be small enough for the nut's first layer to adhere to the bolt's head, but still large enough for them to separate easily.  
We adjusted this gap so that it fits 3D-prints of PLA and ABS.

description.header: Removing the nut from the bolt
description.text:
Make sure you don't cut yourself! Use a thin knife blad and insert it between the bolt's head and the nut. Wiggle it and move it around the bolt until you can feel than the majority of the gap is broken free.  
Remove the knife and carefully unscrew the nut.

We provided several STL files in this thing to fit different 3D printer Z-heights. Choose the STL which fits your 3D printer and scale it slightly if needed. The important thing is not to affect the gap too much when scaling the bolt.

comments.text: I printed the 136mm version, un-scaled, with PLA on a Printrbot metal plus. It was almost perfect. The only flaw was the bottom of the bolt head, and the corresponding top of the nut were thin, you could see voids when I split them apart. The rest of the surfaces were beautiful. I'm wondering if there was a parameter in Cura that would thicken those 2 surfaces. My settings were Layer .2mm, Shell .8mm, Bottom/Top thickness .4mm, Density 10%, The rest of the bolt was virtually flawless, so I don't think the speed (30)  or temperature (205) were an issue. But, I'm new at this, so if anyone has any thoughts on the problem, please let me know.

description.text:
My kit was missing the pulley assemblies, so with a kick in the pants from Thingiverse user and DorkBotPDX awesomeness provider Andrew Parnell, I took to the task of rolling my own with hardware store parts. I've decided that they look so cool I'm going to keep them unless it's later proven that they somehow harm performance. EDIT! Zach points out that original designs running on this had problems with the belt rubbing the washers and ultimately fraying. Only use this method if you, like me, are up z-stage creek without a pulley assembly and need something that'll work for a little while. Andrew Parnell's awesome things are here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/asp55

For each pulley, you'll need: 1 skate bearing (from your MakerBot kit)
1 8m x 35mm bolt
2 8m x 15mm nuts
2 8m inner diameter, 12mm outer diameter washers
2 8m inner diameter, 30mm outer diameter washers Assemble in the order shown on the diagram, pinching the MakerBot frame between the end of the bolt and the first nut. You might get nicer grip with an extra pair of washers on either side of the nut, but I haven't bothered here.

comments.text: Glad to see it worked! (Less glad to see that it will fray the belt....)
comments.author: asp55

comments.text: Amusingly what this really means is that some of the first parts I print will be replacements for the ones used to print them. :D
comments.author: asp55

comments.text: these were how the original pulleys were designed, but there is one flaw:  the belt will rub on the washers and eventually fray.  i would highly suggest printing out your own replacement pulleys once you are up and running.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: So any idea what's different about this that cause rubbing and wear on this but not on the actual pulleys?
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: yeah, on the printed pulleys, the pulley is attached to the outer ring of the skate bearing.  this means that the entire pulley rotates with the belt... no stationary part rubbing on a moving belt.
comments.author: asp55

comments.text: ha ha ha ha ha! wouldnt it be ironic if it broke while printing the pulleys?
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Yep, my first mechanical tests verified that one.  I see it rubbing the top washer just as predicted.  Hopefully in not too long I can print my own replacement to this!
comments.author: Guest

author: MaskedRetriever

title: Arduino Shield Modules for KiCad V2

description.text: This has been replaced by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9630. It has added versions, "*_040pins", with larger pin holes to allow for larger non-stackable pins. This version works perfectly with female stackable header pins but not with many regular male pins. This replaces the prior version. Some of the pins on the Mega were incorrectly labeled. I also re-arranged some pins so that they made more sense. These are modules for both EESchema and PCBNew in KiCad. They will allow you to make PCBs that have the appropriate header positions for a Arduino shield. I adapted files I found on the KiCad yahoo group (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/kicad-users/files/Library/ArduinoShield.ZIP posted by axtz4) adding a version for the MEGA. I have found many Eagle librarys but very few for KiCad, I hope this encourages others to use this great tool and share more KiCad files.
Add these files to your KiCad library & modules folders, add them to your project, and enjoy.

comments.text: The footprint has a design bug. The drill holes have been setup with 0.032" drill holes. However, in order to fit standard 0.1" headers connectors they need to be 0.04". If you produce a shield using this footprint in a factory you probably won't be able to insert your headers.

I decided to have a vacuum cleaner in a cabinet ready for use at all time and with a custom made hook that takes care of the cord and the vacuum hose makes it much more easy to use. The hooks are made to fit a 32mm cabinet system and will take 6.3mm euroscrews directly.

I have printed mine on a Ultimaker 2 with PLA XT from Colorfabb.
0.10mm layer, 4 outer shells and a 60% infill. tested a full 100% infill but that can be broken when putting the screws too too tight also, so I saved some time and placed the screws more carefully and saved some time while printing with a less denser infill. Take is as it is, or get inspired and make something that suits your demands even better.

author: sungjk

title: 3DBotic Filament Guide for Filament Spool Holder

description.text: This filament guide is designed to work with the 3DBotic simple filament spool holder found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36460

UPDATE: 2013-03-31 New version of the STL file uploaded. This version has a thin (2 printed layers) rectangular piece at the tall end of the filament guide. This thin piece keeps the part stuck to the hotbed so that the part cannot warp during printing. It works really well, and is meant to be trimmed off after the part is printed. See the "thingiview" image of the part. I left the old file up if that is your preference. A cooling fan is recommended when printing this part in PLA for either version. 1) This part is designed to work with a Mendel Max that uses aluminum extrusions for the top horizontal frame of the printer.
2) This guide is designed to work with the filament spool holder found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36460
3) Print this part. If printing in PLA, a cooling fan is recommended for the taller section.
4) Use (1) M5 x 10mm Socket Head Cap Screw, 1 M5 T-Slot nut, and 1 M5 washer to attach this guide to the frame, as shown in the photos.
5) Mount this spool holder so it touches the edges (flanges) of the filament spool, and creates a little bit of drag. Not a lot! Just enough to keep the spool from spinning on its own.
6) thread the filament throught this guide then through the top of the printer frame, then down to the extruder. If you already have a filament inserted into your hot end, you will need to heat it up to remove it. This guide can be used with any spools that vary in width between about 65mm to 90mm. Diameter is not critical as the filament guide can be mounted on the vertical frame section and slid up or down as needed to match the spool diameter. Let me know in the comments if a version with a loading slot is desired, and I can modify the design and post it. This will make it easier to load a filament that is already "frozen" into the hot end, but the trade off is a loss of structural strength and stiffness (rigidity) of this part.

These are replacement parts for the board game Blokus.  All parts are represented, so print a full set if you are missing several pieces!  Even the board is printable for those of you with damaged boards.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

<200microns

Infill:

any

To print the board, print 4 of the "Playing Board Quarter" file. These should have the right level of tolerance to fit snugly but not too tight. To print the pieces, you can either use the full plate set of 21 pieces, or pick and choose from the individual files. The file names represent the number of squares in each piece, as well as a word description of what the piece looks like. Make sure the board and all sets of pieces are distinct colors of plastic. Here is a link on how to play the game: http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/leisure/brain-games/blokus1.htm

comments.text: I tried printing some of these for a friend's set, but they came out too large (and yes, I was making it for a standard Blokus set, not a travel set.) Not sure what I'm doing wrong... and I cannot find the right dimension for the pieces so that I could scale them.
comments.author: NatGertler

comments.text: Ah, I now see that there are two different sizes of blokus set. My friend now has one with a larger grey board - that would seem to be the one that these pieces are sized for - and a smaller, white board. If my measurements are right, you need to scale these pieces by 83.19% to get them right, but I haven't verified the results properly.
comments.author: NatGertler

comments.text: How many sizes did Mattel make the board?!? ;)  I had to scale mine to 90.8% for it to fit right (i am printing at .3mm, not sure if that matters much ;)
comments.author: NatGertler

comments.text: I scaled the pieces down to 0.79, printed them at 0.2mm in PLA. Once printed I drilled out the centers with a 15/64" bit and voila! I have replacement pieces for the missing ones in the copy I got at the thrift shop for $1. Thanks for the nice work! I may give a shot at making the whole thing, shrinking it down a little to make it more portable.
comments.author: danrodz

comments.text: Ah, sounds like you have the newer variety of Blokus where there are "pegs" on each square and holes in the pieces.  This was actually made to replace the old kind where they were just solid pieces, but I'm glad you got them to work for you!
comments.author: danrodz

comments.text: Actually somehow I missed mentioning in the post that the missing pieces were for Blokus Duo, the travel sized one. I didn't know the new Blokus came with the peg and hole setup. The pegs in the travel version are square but as I mentioned above, the 15/64" bit did the trick pretty nicely. In any case, I think I will whip a complete version of this and throw it in the camper. Thanks again for the fine work!

description.text:
This game is based off of a similar card game called "No Thanks!" but expands the number of players to 8.  
Play time is about 20 minutes for the 3-5 player version, and 25-30 minutes for the 6-8 player version.  Learning how to play the game takes 1-5 minutes depending on the attention span of the players.  Have fun!  
See the instructions tab for more details.

3D-Print 88 tokens. 2D-Print the 2 included PDFs back-to-back, so that the numbers appear on the one side and the identical backsides are on the back. Or, leave out the backs as they are not necessary to play the game. Cut 9 cards out of each paper when they're done printing, along the gray lines. It is recommended to either print on heavy duty paper, or to laminate the resulting cards. You can also choose to make your own layout with larger or smaller cards using the included zip file of images. For the 3-5 player game, print the cards numbered 3 to 35. For the 6-8 player game, print the cards numbered 3 to 46. To Play: Here is a link to the 3-5 player instructions:
http://zmangames.com/rulebooks/No_Thanks.pdf The 6-8 player instructions are almost exactly the same as the 3-5 player game:
-All players still receive 11 tokens at the beginning of the game.
-play with the 3-46 deck, shuffle the deck, and remove 11 cards instead of 9 cards before playing.

remixed_from.author: tealid
remixed_from.title: Ipad Mini stand (for Mini 1 to 3, 6 plus and more)

description.text:
Hi!  
For christmas i got a Marshall Stanmore Speaker. At home we have it connected to a iPad Mini and i decided to make a nice stand that can be mounted securely on top.  
This model was printed in Laywoo-D3 with 0.1mm layerheight through a 0.5mm nozzle at 220 degrees on a Rapide Lite 200.   
When the three part was printed, they were sanded with 4 different grits and oiled to give them some color. The look and feel of the model turned out amazingly well. Even when up close you cant really grasp the difference on the sanded surfaces.  
As a test i also wanted to see how well i could use wood glue on Laywoo-D3. You sure can - but on this model i decided to take a small screw to secure it to the wooden frame beneath the leathery surface of the speaker.   
Overall this was a really fun project! Hope you enjoy :)

author: Skirkell

description.text: Its a copy of the medallion from the movie Coneheads! Modeled in sketchup and prepped with netfabb.  I'll upload a finished print when i get around to printing.  Have fun!

Never scratch your lens again...or think, "I hope no one saw that." when you are using a screwdriver or other metal object to tighten the ring against the lens.  
This simple disc fits perfectly into the slots on the ring so that you can either tighten by hand or with a regular screw driver.  
Enjoy!

My father has a 4Sight Dashcam with only one view lens, pointing forward. He wanted to be able to pivot it so he could swing it around 180 degrees. He used wood and metal for his prototype (which you can see in the upright, unmounted armature) and then did a pencil sketch with the dimensions he envisioned for a 3D plastic print, and asked me to print out the sleeker plastic version, which I first modeled in SketchUp. He will drill the plastic pieces as he did his first prototype and give it articulation with a wing nut and a washer between the pieces. I printed the first piece from the base up, but flipped it because it is a stronger print when done on its side. I am uploading both versions here.

author: napets777

description.text: Beanie is a transformer that can turn into a car. He can also launch his head off! Just pull the rack puller and his head flies off, hence the name "Beanie"

Assembly is simple! The shorter wheels clip to the feet, the bolts (leg clips) clip the feet to the legs, the longer wheels clip the legs to the hips of the main body, the arm joints (bolts with round ends) go through the "shoulders" and the neck joint. Place the gear in before the neck top, with the + facing upward. Snap the arms into the round sections of the arm joints, with the forearms and claws clipping on through the joints. The head goes on the axle piece and the propeller clips on top. To launch, slide the rack pull into the slot, and then pull! To turn into a car, bend his legs all the way up, rotate the arms around, back over his head, and make sure they are flush with the main body. The claws should latch on just above the "ball holder" of the arm, with the propeller fitting in to the circles under the feet. Any questions or concerns, please let me know!

description.text:
The Bathtub U-Boat,
An Experiment in Large Scale Makerbot Printing. Along with Westerns, Submarine movies are clinically proven to be universally enjoyed by the male population. Admit it, at some point you have walked around wanting to shout 'FIRE TORPEDOES' at the top of you lungs. Well now you can, and look marginally less crazy while doing it. Update November 2013:
A repaired version of these files for use with Makerware and Sli3r are available here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:184992

Attach Part 1a to Part 1 by pressing short segments of 3mm filament into the holes provided. Assemble Parts in numerical order. They should just clip together, but you may need to use and Xacto knife smooth the inner edges for a good fit. Notes: -Parts 1 and 7 at over 14 cm tall. To print at full size on a cupcake, you may need the Lowrider xy carriage modification. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4213 -To control cracking from temperature changes, cover the three open sides of the makebot with cardboard. I can't stress enough the improvement in quality this brings to very large builds. -Parts 5,6,7 and 8 are FIVE HOUR BUILDS! So its got that going for it too. This thing was heavily influenced by:
http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=e97861ceaa8403f02878b5e7fd590014&prevstart=0

description.text: Update 3/22/13 - Still working on this. The contest had me really rushing things, trying to condense things, make things smaller, and fit it all onto one build platform/print. Now I feel free and can start uploading parts of the robot that can be printed separately. Ever watch your hamster or gerbil running in its wheel, wondering if it's imaging that it's traveling to the exotic reaches of the Earth? Well, now it can! Using this creation you can allow your rodent to transform that rotational energy into a walking robot that uses Theo Jansen's miraculous leg linkage! All parts were made specifically for this project, not imported, but some things such as the pins will likely be turned into public customizable libraries for others to use after this project is finished. This project is close to being finished but not quite. Some parts still need finished (wheel to legs assembly) and the gears need printed and tested. The linkage and pins have been printed and work together creating a nice smooth motion. I imagine the wheel itself would be just fine. I have been a really big fan of 3D printing as of late and have been getting into OpenSCAD modeling. I don't have my own 3D printer but I do have access to a couple hours a week from a local club. My development of shared libraries could really use some personal testing and winning this contest would allow me to create many more things for the public good! Still working on generating the STL! I'll unlabel this as a WIP when finished and printable!

Running into issues creating an openscad preview of the assembly. Linkages, body, gears, all will likely change over the next few days as I work on this
  • Try out a set of legs. Print two copies of the leg.stl and one bodyAndThreeGears.stl
  • Put the legs together. Each of the linkages have a number of dots on them to identify. You can use the picture of the legs put together to figure out what goes where.
  • Attach the gears to the body. Looking at the body longways it has 5 pegs on it, the gears will go on the middle three. (Center gear hole!) Keep the outer two gear's holes aligned at the same angle.
  • Attach the legs to either side of the body. Where link three and four go together will go into the outer hole of the outer two gears. The last pin of the body will go into the 'hip' which is the right-triangle looking piece, at the larger angle'd hole.
  • Now you have a working pair of legs! You can hold the body parallel to the ground and use your finger to spin the middle gear and both legs should make a walking motion!
    //----- If you're working on printing this, I'd stop here and wait for me to catch up with the rest of the robot. I have to figure out how to attach the body's to the wheel itself right now. ------//
  • Repeat steps 1-4 three more times to make a total of eight legs.
  • To be continued.

description.text:
This is my entry into the Develop ed's Make-a-bot challenge. as yo can see i have a bit of Iron man and Gundam influence in my robot design, but i don't see emulating masters as a bad thing. as of now this is NOT pose-able. i wanted to have it pose-able, but it just hasn't happened yet. I hope you enjoy CHARGER!
*note: acronym was found at http://cyborg.namedecoder.com

All the parts are in the plated file, and smushed into a build envelope of 130 mm x 150 mm x 130 mm tall, so it can fit most platforms. my printrbot jr is going to need two goes at it, but still. 
the way i have it assembling is with tight tabs that probably should be glued and  will need to be sanded down to fit in the holes(I used a dremel to get mine done quick). I like it that way, much less likely for the parts to come back apart, but watch out fro the small arms and kegs trying to pop off the body. I ended up jb welding 1 leg and 1 arm back on. 
If anyone has any better ideas on how to assemble it, or add pose-able hinges, please let me know.

description.text: This improves on davidmpye's generic case (box and lid) from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28608. The changes should provide improved dimensioning over a wider range of parameters. The lid should fit the box better, and an option has been provided to add a mounting flange. As with davidmpye's design, roundCornersCube.scad from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8812 is used for the basic box. nophead's polyhole.scad is used for creating the small holes. The Rev A files provide a more refined utilization of openSCAD for the designs. More dimensions can be individually tailored. For example, the wall thickness, base thickness, and lid thickness can all be set independently. A table of reference dimension data for common hardware is included in the source file. The mesh overlap between elements has been improved to minimize "ghosting" in the render view. Echo outputs have been added to the console output for key calculation results. The path to roundCornersCube and polyhole have been revised to openSCAD standard library locations. The provided revA STL is a sample output for a 50mm x 70mm x 15mm box and lid with 2.0mm wall thickness. Lid mounting posts are sized for a #4 screw. The sample box shows how board mounting posts can be added to the box bottom, and show how various hole types can be added to the sidewalls and lid. The code for the sample posts and holes is present in the revA openSCAD source, but is commented out. The STL file is provided as a sample output, not necessarily as a box useful to anyone.

Download roundedCornersCube.scad and install it in the openSCAD CUSTOM library location.   
Revise the tailorable parameters in the Generic case improved revA.scad file for the desired box configuration.   The radius for the box corners and the diameter for the lid mounting posts are derived from the hole diameter you specify for the lid corner posts. Review comments throughout the openSCAD file for more information.  Uncomment and tailor the provided sample board mounting posts and box holes, or add your own.  
Edit the top level geometry line to indicate whether you want the lid, the box, or both generated.

description.text: Battery cover for my original GBA was broken for a while, so I decided to model up a replacement for it! Works great printed off of my Printrbot Simple 1405, but YMMV. I've uploaded a second file that is the same thing, but with a snap fit that sits more flush to the back of the cover. This should let your GBA sit flat on its back without wobbling around. If you'd prefer to purchase this from me, check out my Etsy or my Shapeways stores!

Made this while on break and no calipers on hand, so I had to make do with a normal ruler. Some of the measurements might be off because of that, but for the most part it works fine!  
I printed this on its side (hope you can see the lines in the picture) at a 200 micron layer height. You can choose to print it flat if you want, but I don't think it will give you the same flexibility and might be prone to snapping at the bendy parts if you do.

description.text: top graph

This is a half of a nib tray from wtwerner's Agricola Storage Solution (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:134407), for those of us with smaller print volumes. You can print 2 of halfnib.stl and it will fit all the parts, but won't span the full gap in the frame from wtwerner's design. I chose this route to save plastic. It still works nicely, but you might want to put in a piece of dowel underneath it or something to help hold the tray up... If you go this route, you'll need about a 6"x6" print bed. If you chose to print one of each part, you'll get wtwerner's full design, but it will use more filament and you'll need about a 6"x7" print bed at a minimum.

Matt, a grade 12 design student, wanted a place to keep his headset and bits and bobs by his computer. He wanted the top part to swivel so it was designed to work with a skateboard bearing.  
Unfortunately, this design is way too big with the walls being too thick and the diameter too large.  However, we've run out of time to perfect it. While we don't recommend that you print this design, we thought it might serve as inspiration for someone else to make something even more awesome.

title: Case and lid for Tinkerkit T010010 Relay Module

description.text: This is a tailored version of my generic case improvement to davidmpye's generic case (box and lid). The tailored case is dimensioned to fit the Tinkerkit Relay Module, item T010010. Based on my available mounting space, I needed to keep the case small. The basic box dimensions are 45mm x 55mm x 28mm. Holes for the lid mounting are sized for #4 1/4-inch pan head screws. Mounting flanges added to the 45mm sides are also sized for #4 screws. The mounting holes in the Tinkerkit relay module are small, so the internal board mounting standoffs are sized for use with #3-48 1/4-inch flat head screws. Flat head screws are used here in order to reduce the length of standoff required under the board. A simple round hole is provided for routing wires to the relay output terminals. A simple notch is provided for the signal, ground and power wires in case the large interlocking connector is used for the board connection. The design is tailorable through several parameters in the openSCAD file. Like the generic case designs this is based on, it utilizes roundedCornerCube.scad and nophead's polyhole.scad. The Rev A files reflect an update to my generic case improvement at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:643264. Those updates were mainly in parameter labels, paths to the roundedCornerCase and polyhole files, and general file structure. It it no longer necessary to obtain the polyhole file, since it is already included in the openSCAD MCAD library. The Tinkerkit Relay Module provides a 10-amp relay with NO-C-NC connections. The relay operates off of 5V power and signal from an Arduino or similar processor. The relay input is buffered, so only minimal current is required to control the relay.

Print the STL file if the 45x55x28 box is suitable for your needs. For tailoring, download the roundedCornerCase.scad file from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8812. Download the Tinkerkit_relay_case.scad file and edit the line with the correct path location if you don't use the CUSTOM library folder for the roundedCornerCase file. Locate and edit the parameters requiring changes, render, and generate a new STL file.

Tablut, or King's Table, is a variant of several ancient board games generally referred to as Tafl, or more properly Hnefatafl.  
A sort of Viking precursor to chess, Tablut is the best documented variant. All these Tafl games feature a lop-sided distribution of forces and are central to the game.  
This set is suitable for playing standard 9x9 Tablut variants, as well as 7x7 variants by disregarding the outermost border of squares.

The game board itself is designed to be printed on a Replicator 2 at medium quality settings (2mm layer height, 10% infill and two shells) same goes for the game pieces. By printing more pieces and making a larger board, using a system like the modular game board at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7718, you can play the more advanced variants of similar games. I have included Replicator 2-scaled versions of the game pieces and board (whose filename ends in Rep2), as well as full-sized versions for those with larger format printers (these file names end with "scale"). The board itself has tiered squares on the grid to indicate where color changes should go. You may print in a single color and paint the squares on the grid, use filament changes during the print to color them, or use a combination of both, as I did on my example. For those wishing to use filament changes to color the squares, here's a rough procedure for the Rep2 version of the board:
Set a z-height pause for 3mm height. after the pause, resume the print, and wait until the next layer finishes (around 91%). Switch to a dark color such as black. After two more layers (around 96%) change to another color; I used silver. Finally, after two more layers go down (around 98%) switch to your final color for the throne and corner squares; I used translucent yellow to give them a gold finish. of course, using acrylic paint, you can darken the lines in the grid, or enhance the finish of the squares. As for the pieces: you need to print the following: for the white pieces (Swedes)
one (1) king, printed in a light color or gold
eight (8) pawns, printed in a light color. For the black pieces (Muscovites)
sixteen (16) Pawns, printed in a dark color
The Muscovites (black pieces) have no king Rules of Play: There are many variants of play: In general, the king is placed on the throne (center) square, and his soldiers (pawns) are placed around him on the two colored squares around each side of his throne (so the light pieces form a cross, with the king in the middle. the dark pieces are placed in the citadels (black "T" shaped areas on the edges). Some variants have the king surrounded by his soldiers, in all the squares around the throne, forming a box around the king. All pieces move like the rook (castle) in chess. in most variants, the king cannot attack, but in others he may participate as a soldier does. A piece is captured when the enemy moves in such a way that a piece is caught between two pawns (horizontally or vertically, no diagonals) or a single piece and a hostile square.
A piece may be moved between two hostile pieces or a hostile piece and square, and it is not counted as a capture if the lone piece moves there under it's own action. The goal of the light side (Swedes) is to get their king to escape, or by completely eliminating the opposition. The king can escape by entering a corner square in some variants, or by entering a non-hostile square at the edge of the board in others. The goal of the dark side (Muscovites) is to capture the king. unlike other pieces, the king must be captured by boxing it in on four sides (horizontally and vertically) with dark pawns, or in some cases, dark pawns and hostile squares. Hostile squares:
Only the king can occupy the throne. In some variants, once it is moved, it may not re-enter the throne square, and is treated as hostile to all pieces. In other variants, the king may re-enter the throne square at will, and the throne is only hostile to the king's pieces when it is empty. The throne square is always hostile to the dark pieces. In many variants, the corners are hostile to all pieces but the king, who may enter one to win the game. In some variants, the Muscovite citadels (dark "T" shaped regions) are treated as hostile, once a dark piece is moved from the citadel, it may not re-enter, and all citadel squares are treated as hostile like the kings throne. The king may be captured under these rules using only two pieces under certain circumstances, such as being blocked by two citadel squares and two dark pawns.
Furthermore, no piece may pass through the citadel, and can only pass through the two-square region around the throne. In other variants, the citadels are treated like normal squares and may be traveled through freely. For more detailed rules, you can refer to these sources, as well as many others online: Saami Tablut Rules: http://aagenielsen.dk/tablut_rules.php
Foteviken Tablut rules: http://aagenielsen.dk/foteviken_rules_english.html
Aston Tablut rules (as documented in 1732 by Carolus Linnaeus): http://www.heroicage.org/issues/13/ashton.php Additional rules on many variants; Stick to the 9x9 and 7x7 when using my board:
http://aagenielsen.dk/tafl_rules.html A special thanks to Aage Nielsen, who is responsible for collecting all the rules and history in those links! (all the links now point to the proper pages, btw) Feel free to print this off to gift it, or play with your friends; Also feel free to design your own game pieces; half the fun is having a unique set to call your own. I also just added a leaflet in PDF format with basic gameplay instructions which may be printed, folded and included with the set, named "Tablut.pdf". Thanks to Damian Walker for creating this!
Copies of this leaflet, and others for classic and historic games (including more tafl-type games) can be downloaded from his site at:
http://www.cyningstan.com/downloads/529/traditional-board-games-leaflets 11-09-2016: Just updated the link to the Saami Tablut rules; It works again.

title: Printrbot Simple 1405 Z axis wobble stabilizer and z-ext acme nut

description.text:
update 2/7/2016: new v3 version that is flexible via a slotted design. This should let the piece fit tightly while allowing some tolerance for varying print quality. I'm using the 8mm version, which should work fine for most printers.
If you're prints are horrendously wobbly or otherwise inaccurate that a hammer wont make the 8mm fit, there is also an 8.2mm version that fits less tightly over the bars. update 2016: Despite the top cap previously seeming to improve my prints, after rebuilding my printer to replace the acme z nut i once again had very poor sidewalls. I have again achieved nice sidewalls. The difference seems to be in the Z-coupler, which I had to adjust many times after the rebuild to get good prints again.
I currently have a very small amount of separation between the motor shaft and z-rod, about 1mm or less, and had to reseat the z-rod at this height many times, rotating a little relative to the motor shaft each time and doing a test print, before I once again had good walls. V2- now uses a screw on shim to prevent the cap from getting screwed off while also holding the rod tighter. Also added a new z-axis connector thing that extends further down the threaded rod as the original (mine at least) had some slop. Intended to help correct banding on prints. Shimming the bars with a wrap of tape will keep it from screwing off and help with snugness. Also, for anyone trying to get rid of banding my biggest improvement was making a gap between the motor shaft and the threaded rod in the z coupler; my z axis now has about a 1mm of springy movement in it if i push down on it before the threaded rod hits the motor shaft. http://d17kynu4zpq5hy.cloudfront.net/igi/printrbot/nWxUaH1eEPnsiGCT.standard See the middle "2" picture for what I mean. ignore the "bad' label

comments.text: Made this in attempt to help with my printer's z-wobble. It didn't help, and may have actually made the issue worse as it helped transfer more wobble motion from the lead screw to the rails. I discovered that the coupler they send with the kit I got is a pretty dumb design. It has a lot of slop on the lead screw end and only uses one set screw so it pins the lead screw to one side of the hole thus making it not centered over the axis of rotation. If you have a Z-wobble issue and a coupler like I described replace it with a flexible coupler to solve the issue.

description.text:
I created this clock from three ammeters. One tells the hour, one tells minutes, and one tells seconds. There are several ways you can make the clock work: either a specifically designed PIC controller with other electrical components or a Real Time Clock chip and an Arduino Nano circuit board. I am happy to share Arduino code if you would like it to make your clock work. Or you can do what I did and have fun learning Arduino as you build the clock.
There are three holes on the back of the clock box. This was originally intended to allow you to change the time when the clock was going to be controlled by the PIC controller available from http://alan-parekh.com/projects/multimeter-clock-simpson-260/ (the finished clock was actually much simpler than what you can do here.) Feel free to ask questions and I will try to answer when I can. This was a very satisfying project to complete!
Video of the clock in action: http://youtu.be/PNT_aoCKn48

My friends have a split foyer home with a railing on the main level right next to the door.  For whatever reason, I felt like it would make a nice place to hang coats when we visit.  The railing is 1" (25.4mm) square, so the internal sides are 26mm.  I recommend printing at around 50% infill.  They fit quite snug, don't slide around, and hold up my big, double-layer jacket quite well.

These are numbered bases (1 through 10 and 11 through 20) for table top gaming minis with 25mm / 1" round bases.  They come in very handy for DMs when managing a roomful of kobolds.  Any more than that, and your DM is being a jerk.
Updated 2017-01-01: It looks like the 6s and 9s in the original files weren't quite attached to the bases.  That has been fixed.  By request, I also separated the bases into 20 individual files in case you don't want to try and split things in your slicer.  Enjoy!

Updated 02/06/15 Recently I took on the task of moving from my 1405 simple to the bigger and better 1404 printrbot plus. I have redesigned the Rod-ends as well as the bearing blocks to work better as printed parts. I also created a version with an extended X-Carriage which can accommodate larger hotends (the standard one only really works with very skinny ones, not the E3D ones most people love). This is my first posted design;
If you have any questions or suggestions feel free to comment.

Print for regular design:
6x Z-Blocks (V3)
4x Bearing Block (V2)
1x Bearing Block (V2) w/ cutout
1x Bearing Block (V2) w/ cutout & Probe Holes Print for Expanded X-Carriage:
4x Z-Blocks (V3)
2x Y-Blocks (V3)
4x Bearing Block (V2)
1x Bearing Block (V2) w/ cutout
1x Bearing Block (V2) w/ cutout & Probe Holes
1x X-Carriage of choice
1x Fan Mount Bottom if desired Print for E3D usage (BETA):
4x Z-Blocks (V3)
2x Y-Blocks (V3)
4x Bearing Block (V2)
1x Bearing Block (V2) w/ cutout
1x Bearing Block (V2) w/ cutout & Probe Holes
1x X-Carriage E3D
1x E3D Clamp
1x Fan Mount Bottom if desired Laser Cut: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-plus-1404
DISCLAIMER this file is very... rough. I have a revised version that cleans up the holes and is generally much "cleaner" but am not sure I am legally allowed to share it publically as I have removed the Printrbot Logos and texts from the design for when I laser cut my bot.

comments.text: How is it possible to get more space simply from the carriage extension? Do you change the rods to smaller ones to get more space?
comments.author: ma_renaud

comments.text: Basically I extended the X-Carriage by 19mm forward and moved the front 12mm rods forward 19mm as well. This is what the Y-Blocks are for. This leaves more space between the bearing blocks which can accommodate a "fatter" hotend such as the E3D. I personally don't have an E3D V6 so it may not be perfect but I printed a mockup of one and it fits between the blocks. I will look at it tonight and maybe alter it a bit and re-upload that one.
comments.author: ma_renaud

comments.text: I see, it's clever. I have been looking for a way to fit my E3D V6 in there for ages. I will try your solution and post the results.

comments.text: I have updated the files. To use an E3D V6 you need to print my newest design. Assuming you have a working PB plus 1404, print the "Extended X-Carriage E3D" and "E3D Clamp." The only thing I am worried about with this design is the Probe being too long but it SHOULDN'T be an issue. Let me know your findings.
comments.author: ma_renaud

comments.text: I would recommend the "ExtendedX-CarriageCenteredFanless.stl" for you. The other extended carriages either include my fan design or has the hole in the stock position. title: Mudguard washers for Automatic belt tensioner for RepRap Prusa Mendel

description.text:
Building on from the great work of u-design.
During assembly of Automatic belt tensioner for RepRap Prusa Mendel by u-design i discovered I did not have any mudguard washers.
These mudguard washers have a small step close to the inside hole to prevent binding of 608 bearing and washer.
Before this I could not get great looking prints (arcs were not even due to constant slipping due to loose y-axis belt).
A welcome side effect is the I have decreased the voltage to the Y-axis stepper resulting in cooler running :D
Once again thanks to u-design.

• Build a RepRap Prusar Mendel.

  • Have issues with y-axis belt tension.

  • Print u-designs "Automatic belt tensioner for RepRap Prusa Mendel"

  • Print my mudguard washers X 2. I printed with 80% infill (certainly overkill)

  • Assemble and place in RepRap printer.

  • Have fun printing correctly sized/shaped components, trinkets and toys

This version holds window open a few centre meters while also holding it from closing. I'd say it's not a security latch, it keeps our Mr Rascal Cat from jumping out the wrong windows, and stops the window slamming each time the wind blows. Yaye for that. I've uploaded the Gcode for those who want to print it this second.
Prints fine at 1 shell, 10% infill and default speed.,,
Can print at fault high speed pritty well as seen in youtube,
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m0hAQzEHodU A modification that might be worth considering is extruding the upper surface up so making it stronger if you have stronger wind than me.
NOTES about design,
fast print because of,,,
only two ends, rounded ends, rounded corners,width measured to match number of shells so in fills with shells at high speed without jitter. Good luck.
Bye for now and be well from Will and Mr Data :) :]

My Father-in-Law bought a JOBO GPS tracker for his DSLR camera on ebay but it was missing the button to log where you have been (it still worked when taking photos).

Hopefully someone else can use it (although that's unlikely!!).

• Get a JOBO GPS unit without a tracking button (hard to get I imagine).

  • Close GPS unit.

A box to hold RAMPS electronics, with space for a Reprapdiscount smart controller and a 60mm fan.
I was looking for a minimal box with a good fan mount, but couldn't find anything that fit with all the wires and cables.  I've uploaded some pics of the thing wired up - it works!  Fan is a tight fit over the wires, but it's supposed to be.
Make sure you route your wires around the pololu heatsinks.
I was thinking about adding a set of zip tie holes on the front edge for wiring, but it's installed now and I don't want to unplug and replug everything.

Print! The clips holding the arduino in are stiff, but the box is open so you can access all the wiring, so you should only need to insert it once. The fan is held on by zip ties, arduino clips in. The bolt tabs are 4mm. Scad is included if you want to edit it. This was made for (and attached to) my Rostock clone. Source for the whole machine is up on https://github.com/paenian/Rostock-Redux

So a friend of mine asked me to make a replacement clip for his Kia car, its for the door lock, his had broken and guess what he couldn't buy just that bit without buying the compete assembly for lots of $$.
so after a tapping away on the pc for a bit we sat down for a beer while it printed, and there we go, it works!

comments.text: Could I ask what you're using for your black wheels? Do they run along standard T-slot or is it a openbeam/makerbeam specific wheel?
comments.author: RickM

comments.text: I made them on my mini lathe from 20mm dia. derlin rod, design is based on openrail v wheels. I have used them on standard 2020 6mm t slot extrusion, if you planning to use similar design then I would advise v slot extrusion for this.
comments.author: RickM

comments.text: Thanks for the quick reply :) I've got a few different variations of T/V-Slot to try out so will have a play. I'm basically trying to come up with a nice BOM for a delta based reprap that has easy to source, cheap parts as right now so many of them have obscure or expensive components. Ideally I'm trying to get this working with standard Rexroth style 20mm extrusion. They are cheap and whilst they aren't V-Slot, they're not quite T-Slot either.
